DataElement.preferredName: Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation Primary Indication Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the primary indication for the hematopoietic cell transplant.

PermissibleValues.value: Graft failure / rejection after achieving initial hematopoietic recovery
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Graft Failure Post First Hematopoietic Recovery

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Graft Failure Post First Hematopoietic Recovery
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Healthy skin, bone, or other tissue taken from one part of the body and used to replace diseased or injured tissue removed from another part of the body.: loss of ability to function normally.: Post; occuring after.: Preceding all others in time or space or degree.: Pertaining to or related to the formation of blood cells.: gradual healing (through rest) after sickness or injury.

Concepts.definition: Tissue or organ transplanted from a donor to a recipient.
A lack of occurrence or performance.
Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.
Preceding all others in time or space or degree.
Pertaining to or related to the formation of blood cells.
A healing process and/or an outcome implying relative health.  The term is typically used in the context of direct and indirect effects of sickness or injury.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Retained; never-ceasing.: Occurring first in time or sequence; original. (American Heritage Dictionary): Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Involving or composed of different kinds.: Stable; subject to little fluctuation; showing little if any change.: The occurrence in an individual of two or more cell populations of different chromosomal constitutions, derived from different individuals. This contrasts with mosaicism in which the different cell populations are derived from a single individual.

Concepts.definition: Involving or composed of different kinds.
Subject to little fluctuation; showing little if any change.

The occurrence in an individual of two or more cell populations of different chromosomal constitutions, derived from different individuals. This contrasts with mosaicism in which the different cell populations are derived from a single individual.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Loss; a gradual decline in amount or activity.: Or; used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: Reduced; made less in size or amount or degree.: Someone who gives blood or tissue or an organ to be used in another person.: The occurrence in an individual of two or more cell populations of different chromosomal constitutions, derived from different individuals. This contrasts with mosaicism in which the different cell populations are derived from a single individual.

Concepts.definition: A gradual decline in amount or activity.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
Made less in size or amount or degree.
Someone who gives blood or tissue or an organ to be used in another person.

The occurrence in an individual of two or more cell populations of different chromosomal constitutions, derived from different individuals. This contrasts with mosaicism in which the different cell populations are derived from a single individual.

PermissibleValues.value: New malignancy (including PTLD and EBV lymphoma)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: New; having no previous example or precedent or parallel.: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

To devise, contrive, or form in design.
Transference of a tissue or organ within an individual, between individuals of the same species, or between individuals of different species.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not meeting a quantitative or qualitative measure necessary for a requirement.: The occurrence in an individual of two or more cell populations of different chromosomal constitutions, derived from different individuals. This contrasts with mosaicism in which the different cell populations are derived from a single individual.

Concepts.definition: Not meeting a quantitative or qualitative measure necessary for a requirement.

The occurrence in an individual of two or more cell populations of different chromosomal constitutions, derived from different individuals. This contrasts with mosaicism in which the different cell populations are derived from a single individual.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A sudden loss of neurological function secondary to hemorrhage or ischemia in the brain parenchyma due to a vascular event.

Concepts.definition: A sudden loss of neurological function secondary to hemorrhage or ischemia in the brain parenchyma due to a vascular event.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: occurring again.: The sensation of discomfort, distress, or agony, resulting from the stimulation of specialized nerve endings.: An exacerbation of sickle cell disease.

Concepts.definition: Occurring again.
The sensation of discomfort, distress, or agony, resulting from the stimulation of specialized nerve endings.
An exacerbation of sickle cell disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: occurring again.: Persistent and usually painful erection that lasts for at least four hours in the absence of physical or psychological stimulation, which can be caused by hematologic disorders, including sickle cell disease and leukemia, spinal cord injuries, and medications.

Concepts.definition: Occurring again.

Persistent and usually painful erection that lasts for at least four hours in the absence of physical or psychological stimulation, which can be caused by hematologic disorders, including sickle cell disease and leukemia, spinal cord injuries, and medications.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Excessive Blood Transfusion Or Iron Overload Indication

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Excessive Blood Transfusion Or Iron Overload Indication
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Beyond normal limits; unrestrained.: The infusion of components of blood or whole blood into the bloodstream. The blood may be donated from another person, or it may have been taken from the person earlier and stored until needed.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: Accumulation of iron in the tissues. It may be a manifestation of an inherited disorder (e.g., hemochromatosis) or acquired (in patients with repeated blood transfusions). Symptoms include hepatomegaly, arthritis, diabetes mellitus, and bronzed skin. If untreated it has a progressive course and may lead to death.: A sign, signal, circumstance, or symptom which serves to indicate or point out the cause, pathology, treatment, or issue of an attack of disease; the basis for initiation of a treatment for a disease or of a diagnostic test (causal, or symptomatic, or disease-specific indication).

Concepts.definition: Beyond normal limits; unrestrained.
The injection of whole blood or a blood component directly into the bloodstream.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.

Accumulation of iron in the tissues. It may be a manifestation of an inherited disorder (e.g., hemochromatosis) or acquired (in patients with repeated blood transfusions). Symptoms include hepatomegaly, arthritis, diabetes mellitus, and bronzed skin. If untreated it has a progressive course and may lead to death.

A sign, signal, circumstance, or symptom which serves to indicate or point out the cause, pathology, treatment, or issue of an attack of disease; the basis for initiation of a treatment for a disease or of a diagnostic test (causal, or symptomatic, or disease-specific indication).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A vaso-occlusive crisis of the pulmonary vasculature occurring in patients with sickle cell disease. It is characterized by the presence of a new radiodensity on a chest radiograph accompanied by fever, cough, sputum production, dyspnea, or hypoxia.

Concepts.definition: A vaso-occlusive crisis of the pulmonary vasculature occurring in patients with sickle cell disease. It is characterized by the presence of a new radiodensity on a chest radiograph accompanied by fever, cough, sputum production, dyspnea, or hypoxia.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).
